channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Report Ranks China Last in Internet Freedom Among 65 Nations
item.description: The study by the American group Freedom House pointed to China’s strengthening its Great Firewall system of censorship and its criminalizing some kinds of online speech.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: The “Freedom on the Net 2015” report gave China the worst score of 65 nations — behind Iran, Cuba and Myanmar.

item.title: Man Held in Berlin After Body, Believed to Be of Missing 4-Year-Old, Is Found in Car
item.description: The police said the suspect was being questioned in connection to the disappearance of a young asylum seeker who was separated from relatives outside the city’s main refugee registration center.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Mohamed Januzi was separated from his mother and siblings as they waited outside the Berlin Office of Health and Social Affairs to submit asylum applications.

item.title: Floods Paralyze Iraqi Capital, and the Rain Continues
item.description: After a night of intense rainstorms, a joke being shared on social media Thursday assures Iraqis that they don’t need to go far to catch a migrant boat to Europe.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: A flooded street in Baghdad on Thursday. Rare rainstorms began late Wednesday and continued into Thursday, dumping heavy rain on the Iraqi capital and across the country.

item.title: Man Held in Berlin After Body of Refugee, 4, Is Found in Car, Police Say
item.description: The police said the suspect was being questioned in connection to the disappearance of the boy, who was separated from relatives outside the city’s main refugee registration center.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Mohamed Januzi was separated from his mother and siblings as they waited outside the Berlin Office of Health and Social Affairs to submit asylum applications.

item.title: Death Toll From Sinking of Migrants’ Boat Off Greece Rises to 7
item.description: The discovery of the bodies of two children and two adults came a day after the Greek Coast Guard mounted one of its biggest rescue operations this year, saving more than 240.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Refugees and migrants arrived in Athens on Thursday aboard a passenger ferry from the island of Lesbos. A large wooden vessel capsized in high winds on Wednesday, killing seven.

item.title: Santo Domingo Journal: Born Dominican, but Locked Out by Haitian Roots and Lack of ID
item.description: Academics say the Dominican bureaucracy has long sought to block the children of Haitian migrants from gaining an official foothold in the country.
item.category: Kennedy, Robert F, Center for Justice and Human Rights
item.dc:creator: SANDRA E. GARCIA
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yvroze Alphonse, 33, and her children at their home in Batey Naranjo, an impoverished community of sugar cane workers of primarily Haitian descent, on the outskirts of Santo Domingo. Ms. Alphonse moved to the Dominican Republic illegally, but registered herself and her children in the government's naturalization program.

item.title: China to End One-Child Policy, Allowing Families Two Children
item.description: The decision ends decades of restrictive policies that limited most urban families to one child.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Chinese government eased its one-child policy in 2013, but the state news media reported on Thursday that Beijing was abandoning the policy completely.

item.title: Militant Leader Who Organized Attacks in Kashmir Valley Is Killed
item.description: Abdul Rehman, also known as Abu Qasim, of the militant group Lashkar-e-Taiba was killed in a gun battle with security forces, an Indian police official said.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Abdul Rehman, also known as Abu Qasim, “was the most important terrorist operating in the Kashmir Valley,” said S.J.M. Gillani, the police inspector general for the state of Jammu and Kashmir.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Ripples of the Iran Deal
item.description: Iranian- American dialogue is a rebuke to the sterile evasions of Abbas and Netanyahu.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Saudi Blogger Raif Badawi Gets Sakharov Prize, Top E.U. Human Rights Award
item.description: Mr. Badawi, who has been imprisoned and publicly flogged for criticizing his country’s religious establishment, received the award on Thursday.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: Images of the Saudi blogger Raif Badawi during a demonstration in support of him outside the Saudi Embassy in Berlin in June.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Germany’s Gathering Clouds of Discontent
item.description: After a summer of optimism, the country’s voters are turning sour on trade, refugees and Angela Merkel.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JOCHEN BITTNER

item.title: How 4 Federal Lawyers Paved the Way to Kill Osama bin Laden
item.description: The lawyers tried to prepare for any legal obstacles — and made it all but inevitable that Bin Laden would be killed, not captured.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
No Easy Day: The Firsthand Account of the Mission That Killed Osama bin Laden (Book)
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:credit: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images; U.S. Government; Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Stephen W. Preston, the C.I.A.'s general counsel; Mary DeRosa, the National Security Council’s legal adviser; then-Rear Admiral James W. Crawford III, the Joint Chiefs of Staff legal adviser, and Jeh C. Johnson, the Pentagon general counsel worked secretly on clearing legal hurdles for the 2011 raid against Osama bin Laden.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Some Chinese Take Aim at Meat Industry After W.H.O. Report on Cancer Risks
item.description: Many online comments have directed their scorn not at the report that may deprive them of their favorite foods, but at the domestic food industry in China.
item.category: International Agency for Research on Cancer
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman buying meat from a butcher in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou.

item.title: Sony Returns to Profit After Marathon Restructuring Effort
item.description: The company’s mobile phone business struggled, and its film division did less well than a year earlier. But devices and games were bright spots.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Austria and Slovenia Trade Threats as Tensions Over Migrants Grow
item.description: The fragile alliance over migrants in Europe showed signs of strain after Austria and Slovenia threatened to build border fences and Bavaria sought to stem the flow into Germany.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY, BARBARA SURK and ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Migrants in Sentilj, Slovenia, waited to cross into Austria on Tuesday.

item.title: India Wants to Ban Birth Surrogacy for Foreigners
item.description: The latest development in a recent push to regulate an industry that has been booming in India, with one study measuring it at more than $400 million.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Surrogate mothers rest inside a temporary home for surrogates, provided by Akanksha IVF centre, in Anand town, about 70 km (44 miles) south of the western Indian city of Ahmedabad, in August 2013.

item.title: Open Source: Turkish Journalists Report Police Raid on Their Own Offices
item.description: Reporters in Istanbul covered the raid on their offices as the government seized control of a media group critical of the ruling party.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: After a U.S. Shift, Iran Has a Seat at Talks on War in Syria
item.description: Russia has urged the inclusion of representation from Tehran in the Syrian civil war discussions, which will resume in Vienna on Friday.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK, SEWELL CHAN and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, right, after a closed-door meeting on Tuesday with the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee on Syria.

item.title: World Briefing: Violence Creating Refugee Crisis, a U.N. Commissioner Warns
item.description: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said Wednesday that a refugee crisis was looming in Central and North America as people flee unchecked gang violence.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: World Briefing: Nepal: Lawmakers Elect Nation’s First Woman President
item.description: Bidhya Devi Bhandari, 54, the deputy leader of the Communist Party of Nepal Unified Marxist-Leninist, had lobbied actively for a new Constitution.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
